text: This ruling is quite absurd, isn't it? Are we going to start suing websites for having dead links now?
Haha, right? Next thing you know, people will be suing their web browsers for not loading pages fast enough.
I wonder if this ruling will lead to a surge of 404-themed startups. "Your honor, our company was founded on the principle of right to information!"
That sounds like an Onion article. "Startup 'NotFound' Raises $100M to Fight the War on 404 Errors."
"Breaking: NotFound IPO skyrockets, investors flock to the new 'Right to Information' market."
I can't wait to see people's creative solutions to this. Like, what if every 404 error page has a link to a government website where you can request the missing information? 😂
Oh, that would be hilarious! But imagine the workload for the poor government officials who have to deal with those requests. "Request: Please find the missing cat gif from example.com/cats."
I volunteer as tribute! Where do I sign up to become a professional cat gif hunter?
I think the only reasonable solution here is to replace 404 pages with Rickrolls. It's the ultimate balance between information and entertainment. 🎵
You're onto something! At least people won't feel bad about being misled if they're entertained.
THIS IS THE FUTURE! RICKROLLS INSTEAD OF 404s! WHO'S WITH ME?
On a serious note, I wonder how this will affect smaller websites and startups. Will they need to spend more time and resources ensuring there are no dead links?
I think it's a double-edged sword. On one hand, it encourages better website maintenance, but on the other, it puts an unnecessary burden on website owners.
